node.title: Reporting on a Chaotic and Unfamiliar Place That Used to Be Home
node.description: In “O Beautiful,” all that stands between a writer and the career of her dreams is a trip to the land of her nightmares.

node.title: The Superheroes From House of Slay Are Here to Stay
node.description: How five fashion friends got a starring role fighting discrimination and hate in a new comic book series.

node.title: Athletes in a Ravaged Louisiana Town Try to Run Back to Normalcy
node.description: Hurricane Ida knocked down much of Grand Isle, La., but the town’s cross-country team is determined to compete in the state championship meet.

node.title: Two Acclaimed Writers on the Art of Revising Your Life
node.description: Kiese Laymon and Tressie McMillan Cottom on vulnerability, revision and love.

node.title: The Power of Human Touch in the Execution Chamber
node.description: The death penalty is wrong, but we can still uphold the dignity of the condemned.

node.title: Money for Carbon Cuts Is Missing the Mark in the Developing World
node.description: Plans for new power generation won’t meet global climate goals.

node.title: What ‘Structural Racism’ Really Means
node.description: As the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. wrote, “an edifice which produces beggars needs restructuring.”

node.title: Black Voters Want Better Policing, Not Posturing by Progressives
node.description: We need effective, non-militarized policing with accountability for bad officers. Getting that takes hard work, not just rhetoric.

node.title: The Biggest Kink in America’s Supply Chain: Not Enough Truckers
node.description: Long hours and uncomfortable working conditions are leading to a shortage of truck drivers, which has compounded shipping delays in the United States.

node.title: Powell’s Books Survived Amazon. Can It Reinvent Itself After the Pandemic?
node.description: As much as any city, Portland, Ore., has been through hell. Its landmark store, Powell’s Books, must finally build a viable online business while recapturing its downtown success.

node.title: 15-Minute Grocery Delivery Has Come to N.Y.C. Not Everyone Is Happy.
node.description: A half-dozen grocery services offer speed and convenience, but critics worry about their effect on neighborhood stores and crowded city streets.

node.title: It’s Never Too Late to Become a Bollywood Actor
node.description: Richard Klein left behind his life as a Hebrew day school teacher in California and became an actor in Mumbai, often playing a “mean British officer.”

node.title: India Eased Its Covid-19 Disaster. Now Complacency Looms Again.
node.description: The success represents a major victory for Narendra Modi’s government, but a recent slowdown in new vaccinations has sparked worries.

node.title: Singapore will stop covering Covid costs for those who decline to be vaccinated.
node.description: The change, which takes effect on Dec. 8, comes as the number of severe cases has stabilized but remains high, the Health Ministry said.

node.title: The Silent Coup Against Donald Trump Emerged in a Super-Secure Meeting Room
node.description: In this daily series, Newsweek explores the steps that led to the January 6 Capitol Riot.

node.title: Metallurgist admits faking steel tests for US subs
node.description: A metallurgist has pleaded guilty to fraud after faking the results of strength tests on steel.

node.title: Woman, 39, Diagnosed With Terminal Cancer After Being Told She Had IBS
node.description: Claire Gunn, a mother of two, said: "When you've been told you've got incurable cancer, you're living every day thinking 'is it my last?'"

node.title: SpaceX Crew-2 Re-entry Videos Show Astronauts' Fiery Return to Earth Before Splashdown
node.description: The astronauts blazed through Earth's atmosphere aboard a Dragon spacecraft following their six-month mission on the International Space Station.

node.title: Mike Pompeo Says Joe Biden's China Remarks Project 'American Weakness'
node.description: The former secretary of state was responding to recent comments by President Biden, who said the U.S.-China relationship was about competition and not conflict.

node.title: The Jail Oversight Board That Failed to Sound the Alarm
node.description: The Board of Correction, which has the power to monitor Rikers Island and other city jails, took no action as deaths behind bars increased.

node.title: Planning minister to give community a say on Clive Palmer's coal-fired power station proposal
node.description: Clive Palmer's Waratah Coal wants to build a coal-fired power station near the town of Alpha in central western Queensland. The plan is before Barcaldine Regional Council, but Deputy Premier and Planning Minister Steven Miles might take over the approval process.

node.description: The TV and stand-up star talks about loneliness, family, food and his viral Tom Hiddleston video.
